results.title: World of up close
results.creator_credit: Warren Brown and Encyclopaedia Britannica Films
results.brief_description: This film focuses on the unique properties of objects viewed in close-up. It emphasises the importance of colour, shape and texture in identifying familiar objects, while stimulating curiosity about things that cannot be seen unaided by the human eye.

results.title: World of the weed
results.creator_credit: Richard Scott, David Germer and KCET (Television station : Los Angeles, Calif.)
results.brief_description: A dry but carefully measured historical account of marijuana use around the world. From its use in the Chinese Imperial court and as a ritual aid to Hindi mysticism in India, pharmacological properties of hemp have been recognised and exploited over succeeding epochs. Although the film is too broad in its scope to dwell at length on this subject, the film does present an intriguing analysis of more recent attempts at prohibition, which parallel the rise of industrial capitalism and advances in state regulation of civilian behavioural norms.

results.title: World of the waterways
results.creator_credit: Kenneth J. Fairbairn, Edgar H. Anstey and BFT
results.brief_description: Examines the proliferation of Britain Canal Network - man made waterways which cross the country, linking towns, cities, and villages with the river system. After summarising the history of construction, ad noting how the canals were the pre-eminent mode of commercial transport from the 1750s to the rise of rail in the 1850s, the film moves on to look at the waterways today. The canals are predominantly used for leisure cruising, fishing etc but they still have commercial uses, both for bulk transport at a low price and for transporting water from the river system to top up reservoirs for domestic use.
results.creator_credit_for_label: Kenneth J. Fairbairn, Edgar H. Anstey and BFT

results.title: World of plenty
results.brief_description: This wartime story of man and the food necessary for his survival is told by two men - a commentator and an interjector. The many-faceted problem of ensuring adequate production of essential foods, and a fair and even distribution of foods throughout the world, is challengingly presented.

results.title: World of little things
results.creator_credit: Moody Institute of Science. Educational Film Division
results.brief_description: Looks at the historical background of the microscope and studies the life forms often found in a drop of water - amoeba, volvox, paramecium, and didinium. Also shows the structure and nature of other marine life such as medusa and flatworms.

results.title: World of Final Fantasy
results.brief_description: Two twins journey to a mysterious world to rediscover their lost memories. In this peculiar place, the young Mirage Keepers will encounter new friends and familiar Final Fantasy heroes as they learn the truth about their past.

constellations_other.name: Oh, no! Beta!
constellations_other.description: The Sony Betacam BVP-3P was a broadcast-quality camera that used Sony's Beta system, most commonly found in consumer cameras. During the Format Wars in the 1970s and 80s, Beta lost to the cheaper and more accessible Video Home System (VHS).

results.description: Two twins journey to a mysterious world to rediscover their lost memories. In this peculiar place, where stacking things on one’s head is perfectly normal, the young Mirage Keepers will encounter new friends and familiar Final Fantasy heroes as they learn the truth about their past.

results.title: World of darkness
results.brief_description: Edited from the motion picture entitled ‘Strange creatures of the night’, the film examines a variety of creatures, including bats, owls, and a blind lizard that live and hunt in the darkness. Excellent footage of the animals in their natural environment. There is an information booklet inside each can.

results.title: World of change: world of promise
results.creator_credit: William B. Hartigan, Carol Hale and Cinemakers
results.brief_description: Shows the contribution of the World Association of Girl Guides to the changing role of Women in all countries. The work of guides in four contrasting countries - India, Finland, Paraguay and Acapulco - is shown. Despite the different approaches to guiding, the common goals of community awareness and self-improvement are universal.
